questions.question_text: You are driving in a quiet residential area with very little traffic. What hazard must you specifically reckon with?

options.a: Pedestrians will always walk on the right side of the road facing traffic
options.b: Children at play may often run onto the roadway suddenly
options.c: Vehicles will always park on the shoulder

questions.explanation: In residential areas, children often play near the street and may run onto the roadway without looking. Drivers must expect this reckless behavior.

questions.question_text: What must you be prepared for in this situation?

options.a: The children will wait on the pavement until you pass
options.b: One of the children could turn back to collect the ball
options.c: The ball will stop rolling before it enters your lane

questions.explanation: When children are playing with a ball near the road, a child often runs back impulsively to retrieve the ball without checking for traffic.

questions.question_text: You see a pedestrian with a white stick waiting to cross the road. What does this indicate and what must you do?

options.a: The pedestrian is a traffic census officer; you should stop and give details
options.b: The pedestrian is blind; you must reduce speed and stop if necessary to let them cross
options.c: The pedestrian is signaling for a taxi; you may proceed if you are not a taxi

questions.explanation: A white stick identifies a blind or visually impaired pedestrian. Drivers must exercise extreme caution, reduce speed, and be prepared to stop.

questions.question_text: When approaching elderly pedestrians crossing the road, what behavior should you anticipate?

options.a: They often turn back or stop in the middle of the roadway unexpectedly
options.b: They will always run quickly to the other side to avoid delaying traffic
options.c: They are able to judge vehicle speed more accurately than children

questions.explanation: Elderly pedestrians may be unsure or frightened by traffic and can behave erratically, such as stopping or turning back halfway across the street.

questions.question_text: What must you heed in this situation?

options.a: You may pass the stationary bus at walking speed provided you are sure that passengers are not endangered
options.b: You must honk to warn the pedestrians before passing
options.c: You must stop and wait until the bus moves off

questions.explanation: When a bus is stationary (even at a fuel station or stop), you may pass slowly, but only if you are certain pedestrians are safe.

questions.question_text: What must you remember at these bus stops?

options.a: Pedestrians will always use the crosswalk behind the bus
options.b: Pedestrians sometimes step off the roadway without paying attention
options.c: Pedestrians are not allowed to cross until the bus leaves

questions.explanation: Pedestrians near bus stops often rush to catch the bus or step off the curb distractedly without checking for oncoming traffic.

questions.question_text: Why are elderly pedestrians considered to be at higher risk in traffic?

options.a: They are often less agile and cannot judge vehicle speed accurately
options.b: They tend to walk aggressively into traffic to force cars to stop
options.c: They usually wear dark clothing that makes them invisible

questions.explanation: Physical limitations such as poorer eyesight, hearing, and slower reaction times, combined with difficulty judging speed, make elderly pedestrians vulnerable.

questions.question_text: When can a cyclist represent a danger for you?

options.a: When the cyclist signals clearly before turning
options.b: When the cyclist switches to the roadway without paying attention to the traffic
options.c: When the cyclist stays in the cycle lane

questions.explanation: Cyclists merging from the shoulder or a path onto the main road may not look back, creating a collision risk for drivers approaching from behind.

questions.question_text: Why are motorcycles particularly dangerous for car drivers to interact with?

options.a: They are easily overlooked and their speed is often underestimated
options.b: They are too loud and distract drivers
options.c: They take up more road space than cars

questions.explanation: Due to their small profile, motorcycles can be hidden in blind spots ('easily overlooked'), and drivers often misjudge how fast they are approaching.

questions.question_text: Which vehicles must you allow to set off from marked bus stops?
questions.explanation: Regular public transport buses and school buses have priority when leaving a marked stop. You must yield to let them merge.

questions.question_text: What conduct must you expect of children at zebra crossings?

options.a: They will turn around on the zebra crossing for no apparent reason and run back
options.b: They will wait patiently until all cars have stopped
options.c: They will only cross when an adult is present

questions.explanation: Children are unpredictable. Even after starting to cross, they may suddenly turn around and run back to the starting side.

questions.question_text: What do you do in this situation?

options.a: Overtake the van carefully on the right
options.b: I let the pedestrian cross the roadway
options.c: Sound your horn to warn the pedestrian to stay back

questions.explanation: The van has stopped at a crossing (likely to let a pedestrian pass). You must stop and let the pedestrian cross; overtaking here is forbidden.

questions.question_text: A truck stops in the left lane at a zebra crossing. You are driving in the right lane. What do you do?

options.a: Wait because pedestrians might be crossing the roadway in front of the truck
options.b: Proceed cautiously because you have the right of way in your lane
options.c: Accelerate to pass the truck before any pedestrians appear

questions.explanation: If a vehicle stops at a crossing, it is almost certainly for a pedestrian. Even if you cannot see them concealed by the truck, you must stop.

questions.question_text: Why is it particularly important to brake in good time when approaching a zebra crossing?

options.a: So that pedestrians are not scared or made insecure
options.c: Because the road surface is always slippery there

questions.explanation: Approaching fast frightens pedestrians. Braking early signals your intent to yield, giving them the confidence to cross safely.

questions.question_text: Look at the diagram. You are the Red car and you want to go straight (taking the 2nd exit). Which path is correct?

options.a: The path taken by the Blue car
options.b: The path taken by the Red car

questions.explanation: When going straight through a roundabout (12 o'clock), you should typically stay in the left (outside) lane, as shown by the red arrow.
